awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Long-term studies of secondary succession and community assembly in the prairie-forest ecotone of eastern Kansas
awd_abstract_narration:
Long-term studies are increasingly valuable as a means to evaluate and predict the responses of ecosystems to multiple global changes. This research program employs two long-term field experiments in Kansas grassland to evaluate the interplay of soil fertility, plant species interactions and regional processes governing the recovery of vegetation, biodiversity and ecosystem function on abandoned agricultural lands. Results from these long-term experiments will continue to yield basic insights into the dynamics and functioning of ecological communities following disturbance and in response to excess nutrients. The results will also inform the management, conservation and restoration of native grasslands. The project will continue to contribute to the development of the University of Kansas Field Station (KUFS), complement ongoing research at KUFS in grassland and restoration ecology, and support the education and training of graduate, undergraduate and high school students.

These long-term experiments involve the manipulation of soil nutrient availability via fertilization and employ multi-species propagule additions to evaluate the contribution of plant propagule availability in the regulation of plant community and ecosystem dynamics. Experiment 1 involves factorial manipulations of soil Nitrogen (N) and Phosphorus (P) and was established on a site that was plowed prior to the initiation of the study, permitting examination of plant community assembly in the context of secondary succession initiated on bare soil. Experiment 2 involves factorial manipulations of N and annual haying. This experiment parallels Experiment 1 with manipulations of soil resources and propagule pools, but does so with different initial conditions and in the context of hay management and prairie hay meadow restoration. Together these complementary experiments address a range of questions and hypotheses in community ecology emerging from six related themes that will continue to guide research: 1) species coexistence and diversity; 2) patterns and mechanisms of ecological succession; 3) community assembly and meta-community dynamics; 4) linkage between community structure and ecosystem function; 5) grassland restoration and management; 6) collaborative research in community and ecosystem ecology. Continued sampling of both experiments for another five years will extend the core data sets (plant species abundances and productivity data) to a 21-year time series and permit comprehensive syntheses of vegetation dynamics over two-decades.

por.por_cntn:
Eutrophication, the exposure of ecosystems to excess nutrients, is an important dimension of human-driven global change that threatens terrestrial and aquatic habitats worldwide. Our long-term field experiments conducted on abandoned agricultural lands in eastern Kansas between 2001 and 2023 explored the effects of excess Nitrogen (N) and Phosphorus (P) supply on plant composition, diversity, and patterns of ecological change over time in grasslands recovering from past disturbance. The study is comprised of two related fertilization experiments initiated in 2001 at the University of Kansas Field Station. One experiment examined how increased N and P availability combine to regulate grassland composition and dynamics after land abandonment from row-crop agriculture. The second experiment examined how increased N availability interacted with haying management to impact grassland composition and change. Both experiments involved the experimental seed addition of native prairie plants to half of the experimental plots. This was done to: 1) explore how grassland composition and dynamics in response to nutrient fertilization may be altered by the availability of native plant species that had previously been extirpated from the area; and 2) evaluate the potential impacts of nutrient eutrophication on efforts to restore native prairie grassland from seed on disturbed, post-agricultural lands.

Long-term data collected from annual surveys of these experiments have shown that, in general, nutrient additions have produced only modest declines in plant diversity but caused profound changes in plant species composition that amplified over time. Moreover, divergence in plant composition between control and fertilized plots increased as a function of the amount of nutrient added. In both experiments, perennial and native plant species rose to dominance over time in control treatments as the grassland communities developed, especially when native prairie species had been added as seed. In contrast, fertilized plots, especially those receiving the most nutrients, were resistant to the establishment of native species, even when natives had been added as seed. These nutrient enriched communities diverged from the control plots over time and formed unstable communities dominated by non-native annuals, exotic weedy grasses, and shrubs. Our work indicates that these changes in composition toward unstable, non-native and weedy species dominance, especially at the highest rates of nutrient supply, are driven by shifts in competitive interactions in favor of non-natives over natives. Our work also suggests that these competitive shifts are at least partially driven by the suppressive effects of nutrient enrichment (particularly N enrichment) on the beneficial relationships between many prairie plant species and their fungal mutualists.

Our findings confirm the general role of excess nutrients in destabilizing ecological communities and causing biodiversity homogenization and loss. This study illustrates the profound challenge of restoring tallgrass prairie on post-agricultural lands that have nutrient rich soils or that are exposed continually to excess nutrient supply rates. Tools to mitigate excess nutrients are key to the successful restoration of native prairie grasslands on degraded post-agricultural lands.

Beyond the scientific contributions and applied implications of our findings for ecological restoration, our long-term project has had a number of broader societal impacts. These include: the production of two long-term data sets, available to the public to explore effects of nutrient enrichment on plant community dynamics; and the involvement, employment, training, and professional development of numerous undergraduate students, graduate students, and other participants.
